titleStmt.title: Letter, William Smith in Nashville, Tenn., to Eliza Smith in Binghamton, N.Y., 1865

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

availability.p: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

bibl.title: Letter, William Smith in Nashville, Tenn., to Eliza Smith in Binghamton, N.Y., 1865

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for The University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Corrections have been applied to the text only where there is a high degree of certainty of an error and if the correct spelling is known.
Corrections are represented by editorial tags.
Quotation marks and apostrophes have been replaced by entity references.
All unambiguous end-of-line hyphens have been removed.
Names of persons, places, and organizations are indicated in the transcription when identifiable with a high degree of certainty.

keywords.term: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Correspondence.
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Engineering and construction.
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Manuscripts.

revisionDesc.change: Added "idno" element, editorial declaration statement, subjects/keywords and abstracts from EAD finding aid. Removed box and folder notes, reference declaration element. Changed the formatting for blank pages. Added resp attributes to editorial changes, and added name tags.
Deleted n= attribute of TEI element, updated availability statement to include hyperlink, updated pagination to reflect envelopes being changed to back matter, removed superscript markup.

div.p:
my dear wife i would like you to him he like a skeloton he is so poor like a skleton his poor face in fell in and is eyes are black all round that you would not know him tell austin I would like him to see is der brother now alfred is grone very tall since he came here henry wheler tolde that Alfreds Bowels are been very bade again for a full month he ought then to have come home then my dear wife I have much more to say now pleased to write to me
as quick a posable and tell me what you have to say about my de Alfred I must conclude with my kinde love to all of this time write an donte delay a minit before write back to me again I he olles werse I will rie back again as quck as posable I ham gone your loveing husband William Smithe
